Source: COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective in protecting you against COVID-19.

Source: These antibodies help your immune system fight the virus if exposed to it.

Source: COVID-19 vaccines provide strong protection against serious illness, hospitalisation, and death.
Followup: COVID-19 vaccines does not provide strong protection against serious illness, hospitalisation, and death.
Result: The COVID-19 vaccine does not provide strong protection against serious illness, hospitalization, and death.

Source: Getting vaccinated helps those at a higher risk of falling seriously ill have an increased immunity, such as people who are severely immunocompromised, pregnant (including their unborn baby), adults aged above 65 years, and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Followup: Getting vaccinated helps those at a higher risk of falling seriously ill have an increased immunity, such as people who are not severely immunocompromised, pregnant (including their unborn baby), adults aged above 65 years, and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Result: Vaccination helps boost immunity in people who do not have severe immune compromise, pregnant women (including unborn babies), adults 65 years of age or older, and people at higher risk of serious illness, such as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents.

Source: mRNA vaccines (Pfizer and Moderna) are safe and effective for children.
Followup: mRNA vaccines (Pfizer and Moderna) are not safe and effective for children.
Result: mRNA vaccines (Pfizer and Moderna) are not safe and effective in children.

Source: Three doses of the vaccine have proven to provide stronger and longer-lasting protection.

Result: A stronger, longer-lasting protection has not been demonstrated with three doses.

Source: Getting vaccinated is a safer and more dependable way to build immunity to COVID-19 than getting sick with COVID-19.
Followup: Getting vaccinated is not a safer and more dependable way to build immunity to COVID-19 than getting sick with COVID-19.
Result: Vaccination is no safer and more reliable way to build immunity against COVID-19 than getting it.

Source: If you had COVID-19, you should still get vaccinated to receive maximum protection.
Followup: If you had COVID-19, you should not still get vaccinated to receive maximum protection.
Result: If you are infected with COVID-19, you should still not be vaccinated for maximum protection.

Source: And this question would be the first of many he'd confront from this armchair over the coming two and a half years.

“I knew that I was essentially broken,” he says.
“My attitude was, crack me open and pour me out onto the table. Let’s figure this thing out.”
I'm in this by myself.

Source: COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective in protecting you against COVID-19.

BEYOND BLUE STORY https://www.beyondblue.org.au/personal-best/pillar/supporting-yourself/i-came-because-i-didn't-want-to-die-jake-s-story-of-anxiety-depression-and-therapy
From a place of hopelessness, Jake has come to accept that he's worth recovering for.
It was Jake’s first session with a psychologist.
And this question would be the first of many he'd confront from this armchair over the coming two and a half years.
While it was hard to answer, Jake realised that for the first time in his 22 years, he wanted to find the answers.
“I knew that I was essentially broken,” he says.
“My attitude was, crack me open and pour me out onto the table. Let’s figure this thing out.”
I'm in this by myself.
I have someone that I can talk to and get a perspective from.

A third primary dose is recommended for people in this age group who are severely immunocompromised.
It is recommended they receive this dose from 8 weeks after their second dose.
People aged 16 to 17 are also recommended to receive an additional dose after their primary course of vaccination.
This will be a third dose for most people.
However, for people who are severely immunocompromised, an additional dose will be a fourth dose, as they will already have had 3 primary vaccine doses.

Everyone aged 16 and over who is severely immunocompromised or lives in disability care facilities can receive their winter dose 3 months after receiving their third dose (or fourth dose for people who are severely immunocompromised) or being infected with COVID-19 if it has occurred since the person's third dose.
People aged 16 to 17 can get the Pfizer, Moderna or Novavax vaccine for their primary course of vaccination.
The primary course of vaccination is the first two doses, or three doses for people who are severely immunocompromised.

They are eligible to receive a Pfizer vaccine for this additional third or fourth (for people who are severely immunocompromised) dose and a Pfizer vaccine for their winter dose (for those who are eligible to receive this dose).
Free COVID-19 vaccines are available at vaccination hubs, pharmacies and GPs.
Use the Victorian Government online booking system or call 1800 675 398 (7 days a week, 8 am to 8 pm) to book your vaccine appointment. For an interpreter, press zero (0).
You can also request an Auslan interpreter when making your booking.
See the locations of all vaccination centres, including sites offering walk-in appointments.
To make a booking with a GP or pharmacy, use the Australian Government’s Vaccination Clinic Finder
You need a third dose to keep up your immunity against COVID-19.
Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) recommends COVID-19 third doses for anyone aged 16 and over who received their second dose 3 or more months ago.
The Pfizer, Moderna and Novavax vaccines are approved for use as a third dose in people aged 18 years and over, regardless of which COVID-19 vaccine you received for your initial doses.
People aged 16 to 17 will receive the Pfizer vaccine as their third dose.

The AstraZeneca vaccine is only recommended for use as a third dose if you have had a significant adverse reaction to a previous mRNA vaccine dose (for example, Pfizer or Moderna) that means you cannot have another dose of an mRNA vaccine.
ATAGI does not recommend AstraZeneca for use as a third dose for people who received AstraZeneca for their first two doses.
If you’re not sure which third dose you’re eligible for, talk to your GP.
Your third dose will appear on your Australian immunisation history statement and your COVID-19 digital certificate.

Under Pandemic Orders, workers in key sectors who are already required to be up to date with their vaccination status with two doses, must get their third dose before being permitted to work on site. Visit Worker vaccination requirements for more information.
If you completed your initial vaccination course overseas with a vaccine recognised by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, you can get your third dose.
BEYOND BLUE STORY https://www.beyondblue.org.au/personal-best/pillar/supporting-yourself/i-came-because-i-didn't-want-to-die-jake-s-story-of-anxiety-depression-and-therapy
From a place of hopelessness, Jake has come to accept that he's worth recovering for.
It was Jake’s first session with a psychologist.
And this question would be the first of many he'd confront from this armchair over the coming two and a half years.
While it was hard to answer, Jake realised that for the first time in his 22 years, he wanted to find the answers.
“I knew that I was essentially broken,” he says.
“My attitude was, crack me open and pour me out onto the table. Let’s figure this thing out.”
I'm in this by myself.
I have someone that I can talk to and get a perspective from.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare estimates that up to 472,000 Australians are living with dementia.
In 2019, dementia was the second leading cause of death in Australia, and the leading cause of death among Australian women.
In Australia, 1 in 12 people aged 65 and over are living with dementia
In Australia, 2 in 5 people aged 90 and over are living with dementia
In Australia, dementia prevalence rates are 3-5 times higher among Indigenous Australians.

Source: BEYOND BLUE STORY https://www.beyondblue.org.au/personal-best/pillar/supporting-yourself/i-came-because-i-didn't-want-to-die-jake-s-story-of-anxiety-depression-and-therapy
From a place of hopelessness, Jake has come to accept that he's worth recovering for.
It was Jake’s first session with a psychologist.
And this question would be the first of many he'd confront from this armchair over the coming two and a half years.
While it was hard to answer, Jake realised that for the first time in his 22 years, he wanted to find the answers.
“I knew that I was essentially broken,” he says.
“My attitude was, crack me open and pour me out onto the table. Let’s figure this thing out.”
I'm in this by myself.
I have someone that I can talk to and get a perspective from.

Source: BEYOND BLUE STORY https://www.beyondblue.org.au/personal-best/pillar/supporting-yourself/i-came-because-i-didn't-want-to-die-jake-s-story-of-anxiety-depression-and-therapy
From a place of hopelessness, Jake has come to accept that he's worth recovering for.
It was Jake’s first session with a psychologist.
And this question would be the first of many he'd confront from this armchair over the coming two and a half years.
While it was hard to answer, Jake realised that for the first time in his 22 years, he wanted to find the answers.
“I knew that I was essentially broken,” he says.
“My attitude was, crack me open and pour me out onto the table. Let’s figure this thing out.”
I'm in this by myself.
I have someone that I can talk to and get a perspective from.

Source: The World Health Organisation defines dementia as a syndrome that leads to a decline in the ability to process thought, beyond what is expected from the usual consequences of ageing.
Followup: A decline in the ability to process thought, beyond what is sometimes expected from the usual consequences of ageing, is the result of a syndrome, defined by The World Health Organisation as dementia.
Result: A decline in the ability to process thoughts, beyond what is sometimes expected from the normal consequences of aging, is the result of a syndrome defined by the World Health Organization as dementia.

Source: Dementia can affect a person’s: memory, thinking, behaviour, communication, judgement, ability to perform daily activities.
Followup: Memory, thinking, behaviour, communication, judgement, ability to perform daily activities, are under the effects of dementia to a person.
Result: Memory, thinking, behaviour, communication, judgement, ability to carry out daily activities are under the influence of dementia for a person.

Source: Dementia can affect anyone of any age; however, it is most common among people aged 65 years and older.
Followup: People aged 65 years and older are most common to be affected by dementia.
Result: People aged 65 and older are most often affected by dementia.

Source: While ageing increases your risk of dementia, it is not a normal part of ageing.
Followup: Ageing does not increases your risk of dementia.
Result: Aging does not increase the risk of dementia.

Source: Younger onset dementia describes any form of dementia affecting a person under the age of 65.
Followup: A person under the age of 65 affected by any form of dementia, is described by younger onset dementia
Result: A person under the age of 65 who is affected by any form of dementia is described by younger-onset dementia

Source: There are multiple types of dementia, including: Alzheimer’s disease, vascular dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, frontotemporal dementia, alcohol-related dementia, younger onset dementia, chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).
Followup: Alzheimer’s disease, vascular dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, frontotemporal dementia, alcohol-related dementia, younger onset dementia, chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), are types of dementia
Result: Alzheimer's disease, vascular dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, frontotemporal dementia, alcohol-related dementia, younger-onset dementia, chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), are types of dementia

Source: Some risk factors for dementia can be reduced by looking after your mental and physical health.
Followup: Looking after your mental and physical health can reduce some risks of dementia
Result: Taking care of your mental and physical health can reduce some risks of dementia

Source: Several factors can contribute to the risk of developing dementia, including: age, genetics and family history, poor diet, lack of exercise, smoking, drinking alcohol, social isolation, other diseases or causes of damage to the brain.
Followup: Age, genetics and family history, poor diet, lack of exercise, smoking, drinking alcohol, social isolation, other diseases or causes of damage to the brain are some of the factors can contribute to the risk of developing dementia
Result: Age, genetics and family history, poor diet, lack of exercise, smoking, drinking alcohol, social isolation, other diseases or causes of brain damage are some of the factors that can contribute to the risk of developing dementia

Source: To lower your risk of developing dementia, you can: improve or maintain your physical health through diet and exercise, limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking, maintain an active social life, keep mentally stimulated.
Followup: Improve or maintain your physical health through diet and exercise, limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking, maintain an active social life, keep mentally stimulated can lower your risk of developing dementia
Result: Improving or maintaining your physical health through diet and exercise, limiting alcohol consumption and avoiding smoking, maintaining an active social life, keeping yourself mentally stimulated can reduce the risk of developing dementia

Source: The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare estimates that up to 472,000 Australians are living with dementia.
Followup: Up to 472,000 Australians are living with dementia as estimated by The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare
Result: Up to 472,000 Australians are living with dementia as estimated by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare

Source: In 2019, dementia was the second leading cause of death in Australia, and the leading cause of death among Australian women.
Followup: The second leading cause of death in Australia, and the leading cause of death among Australian women was dementia in 2019.
Result: The second leading cause of death in Australia, and the leading cause of death among Australian women was dementia in 2019.

Source: In Australia, 1 in 12 people aged 65 and over are living with dementia
In Australia, 2 in 5 people aged 90 and over are living with dementia
In Australia, dementia prevalence rates are 3-5 times higher among Indigenous Australians.
Followup: Indigenous Australians are 3-5 times more prevalence to dementia in Australia
Result: Indigenous Australians are 3-5 times more prevalent for dementia in Australia

Source: The symptoms of dementia can vary depending on the person, the type of dementia and whether they have an early, middle or late stage of cognitive decline.

People living with dementia may experience a range of signs and symptoms, including: memory loss, changes in personality, confusion about time or place, difficulty speaking, writing, and comprehending, loss of emotion, interest and enthusiasm, reduced, capacity for decision-making, difficulty performing everyday tasks, irregular sleep.
Followup: Memory loss, changes in personality, confusion about time or place, difficulty speaking, writing, and comprehending, loss of emotion, interest and enthusiasm, reduced, capacity for decision-making, difficulty performing everyday tasks, irregular sleep are the signs and symptoms of people living with dementia.
Result: Memory loss, changes in personality, confusion about time or place, difficulty speaking, writing and understanding, loss of emotion, interest and enthusiasm, reduced ability to make decisions, difficulty carrying out everyday tasks, irregular sleep are signs and symptoms of people living with dementia.

Source: The signs and symptoms of dementia may not be obvious.
If you notice any changes that are unusual for you, see your doctor.
It is important to receive a confirmed diagnosis from your doctor.

To diagnose you, your doctor will ask you to provide your medical history and may conduct: physical and neurological examinations, cognitive and mental state assessment, blood or urine tests, specialist tests, such as a CT or MRI of the brain.
Followup: Physical and neurological examinations, cognitive and mental state assessment, blood or urine tests, specialist tests, such as a CT or MRI of the brain, maybe conducted by your doctor to diagnose you.
Result: Physical and neurological examinations, cognitive and mental state assessment, blood or urine tests, specialist tests, such as a CT or MRI of the brain, may be performed by your doctor to diagnose you.

Source: Currently there is no treatment available to cure dementia.
Followup: Dementia is currently incurable.
Result: Dementia is currently incurable.

Source: Symptoms can often be managed, which can help people with dementia live meaningful and fulfilling lives after diagnosis.
Non-medicinal approaches can help to manage the challenging behaviours of dementia.
Followup: The challenging behaviours of dementia can be managed by non-medicinal approaches
Result: The challenging behaviors of dementia can be managed by non-medical approaches

Source: Non-medicinal approaches include: psychological therapies, including cognitive behavioural therapies, alternative therapies, including multi-sensory therapy, memory training and activities, changes to a person’s home or other environment to ensure it is dementia-friendly.
Medicinal approaches aim to: improve memory, thinking, and sleep, reduce delusions or hallucinations, reduce depression and anxiety.
Followup: Improving memory, thinking, and sleep, reducing delusions or hallucinations, reducing depression and anxiety, are the goals of medicinal approaches.
Result: Improving memory, thinking and sleep, reducing delusions or hallucinations, reducing depression and anxiety are the goals of medical approaches.

Source: Our initiatives and programs support people living with dementia and their carers at every stage – from diagnosis through to residential aged care.
Followup: People living with dementia and their carers at every stage – from diagnosis through to residential aged care, are supported by our initiatives and programs.
Result: People living with dementia and their carers at all stages – from diagnosis to residential aged care are supported by our initiatives and programmes.

Source: These measures aim to: improve dementia diagnosis and early intervention, increase respite and support for informal carers, improve the capacity and quality of dementia care.
Followup: Improving dementia diagnosis and early intervention, increasing respite and support for informal carers, improving the capacity and quality of dementia care, are the goals of these measures.
Result: Improvement of dementia diagnosis and early intervention, increased respite and support for informal carers, better capacity and quality of dementia care, are the goals of these measures.

Source: This will ensure that people living with dementia are: connected with the support they need after their diagnosis, enabled to remain in their home for longer, able to access high quality, dementia informed aged care services.

A healthy weight is the appropriate body weight for you – it is different for everyone and depends on your: gender, age, height, muscle mass, biological and genetic factors, including ethnic background.
You can determine whether your weight is in the healthy range, by working out your body mass index (BMI). A healthy BMI range is 18.5 to 24.9.
Followup: Your body mass index (BMI) can be used to determine whether your weight is in the healthy range. A healthy BMI range is 18.5 to 24.9.
Result: Your body mass index (BMI) can be used to determine if your weight is in a healthy range. A healthy BMI range is 18.5 to 24.9.

Source: But the BMI doesn’t take account of body shape or fitness levels.
Followup: Body shape or fitness levels does not affect BMI.
Result: Body shape or fitness level does not affect BMI.

Source: For example, an athlete might have a BMI in the overweight range due to muscle mass.
Followup: For example, muscle mass can cause an athlete to be in a BMI in the overweight range.
Result: For example, muscle mass may cause an athlete to be in the overweight BMI range.

Source: So, measuring waist circumference, as well as BMI, can help determine whether you could be at risk of some chronic conditions.
If you are worried about your weight, speak to your doctor.
Followup: Speak to your doctor if you are worried about your weight
Result: Talk to your doctor if you are concerned about your weight

Source: Being a healthy weight provides better quality of life – including feeling better, having more energy, and having a higher self-esteem
Followup: Feeling better, having more energy, and having a higher self-esteem is the benefit of being a healthy weight.
Result: Feeling better, having more energy, and having higher self-esteem are benefits of a healthy weight.

Source: Being a healthy weight reduces the risk of ill-health – overweight and obesity is a major risk factor for many conditions
Followup: Overweight and obesity is a major risk factor for many conditions and being a healthy weight reduces those risk.
Result: Being overweight and obese is a major risk factor for many conditions, and a healthy weight reduces that risk.

Source: Being a healthy weight makes it easier to manage chronic conditions
Followup: It is easier to manage chronic conditions if you are at a healthy weight.
Result: Chronic conditions are easier to manage if you are at a healthy weight.

Source: Being a healthy weight helps improve mental health – being overweight or obese can contribute to mental ill-health, including low self-esteem, depression and anxiety
Followup: Being overweight or obese can contribute to mental ill-health, including low self-esteem, depression and anxiety, these can be improve by being a healthy weight.
Result: Being overweight or obese can contribute to mental health, including low self-esteem, depression and anxiety, and these can be improved by being at a healthy weight.

Source: Being a healthy weight helps you live longer – on average, people with BMIs of 30 to 35 die 2 to 4 years earlier than those with healthy weight, while those with BMIs of 40 to 45 die 8 to 10 years earlier.
Followup: On average, people with BMIs of 30 to 35 die 2 to 4 years earlier than those with healthy weight, while those with BMIs of 40 to 45 die 8 to 10 years earlier, so you live longer from being a healthy weight.
Result: On average, people with a BMI of 30 to 35 die 2 to 4 years earlier than those at a healthy weight, while those with a BMI of 40 to 45 die 8 to 10 years earlier, so you live longer than a healthy weight.

Source: Being overweight or obese increases the risk of heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, some cancers, kidney disease, gall bladder disease, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, joint problems, such as gout, arthritis and joint pain, sleep problems, sexual health problems, having a difficult pregnancy and labour.
Followup: The risk of heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, some cancers, kidney disease, gall bladder disease, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, joint problems, such as gout, arthritis and joint pain, sleep problems, sexual health problems, having a difficult pregnancy and labour increases from being overweight or obese.
Result: Risk of heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, some cancers, kidney disease, gallbladder disease, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, joint problems such as gout, arthritis and joint pain, sleep problems, problems with sexual health, difficult pregnancy and childbirth increase from being overweight or obese.

Source: The higher the excess weight, the higher the risk of developing these conditions.
Being overweight or obese can also make it harder to control or manage existing chronic conditions.
Followup: Existing chronic conditions can be harder to control or manage if you are overweight or obese.
Result: Existing chronic conditions may be more difficult to control or manage if you are overweight or obese.

Source: Overweight and obesity is a major – but largely preventable – public health issue in Australia.
In 2019, out of 22 OECD member countries, Australia had the 6th highest proportion of overweight or obese people aged 15 and over.
Followup: The 6th highest proportion of overweight or obese people aged 15 and over out of 22 OECD member countries in 2019, is Australia.
Result: Australia has the 6th highest proportion of overweight or obese people aged 15 and over out of 22 OECD countries in 2019.

Source: In Australia, 1 in 4 children aged 2 to 17 are overweight or obese
In Australia, 2 in 3 adults are overweight (36%) or obese (31%)
In Australia, about 2 in 3 adults have a waist circumference that puts them at high risk of chronic disease
In Australia, overweight and obesity increases with age – in 2017–18, 46% of those aged 18 to 24 years were overweight or obese, compared with 75% of those aged 55 to 64 years
Followup: Compared with 75% of those aged 55 to 64 years, 46% of those aged 18 to 24 years were overweight or obese in 2017–18, so overweight and obesity increases with age In Australia
Result: Compared to 75% of those aged 55 to 64, 46% of those aged 18 to 24 were overweight or obese in 2017–18, so overweight and obesity increase with age in Australia

Source: In Australia, those aged 65 to 74 years are the most likely of all age groups to be overweight or obese (78%)
In Australia, 8.4% of the total burden of disease was due to overweight and obesity in 2015.
Followup: In 2015, overweight and obesity caused 8.4% of the total burden of disease in Australia.
Result: In 2015, overweight and obesity accounted for 8.4% of the total burden of disease in Australia.

Source: Excess weight generally results from an energy imbalance.
Followup: An energy imbalance results in excess weight generally.
Result: Energy imbalance generally leads to excess weight.

Source: This is where the energy taken in from eating and drinking is higher than the energy used through physical activity.
Followup: The energy used through physical activity is lower than the energy taken in from eating and drinking in this case.
Result: In this case, the energy used by physical activity is less than the energy consumed by eating and drinking.

Source: Eating healthy food and being physically active are important to achieving a healthy weight.

Result: To achieve a healthy weight, it is important to eat healthy foods and be physically active.

Source: But many other factors come into play – if you’re worried about your weight, or having trouble maintaining a healthy weight, speak with your doctor.

Result: Talk to your doctor if you are concerned about your weight or have trouble maintaining a healthy weight because many other factors come into play.

Result: Higher prices for healthy and fresh food is one of the challenges in regional and rural areas compared to cities

Result: Less availability of fresh fruits and vegetables, as well as healthier substitutes such as whole grain bread and reduced-fat milk, is one of the challenges in regional and rural areas compared to cities

Result: Poorer drinking water, which can lead people to drink more sugary drinks, is one of the challenges in regional and rural areas compared to cities

Source: When compared with cities, challenges in regional and rural areas include fewer indoor gyms, sporting grounds or team sports.

Result: Fewer indoor gyms, sports fields or team sports is one of the challenges in regional and rural areas compared to cities

Source: There are things you can do to eat healthily and be active.

Source: BEYOND BLUE STORY https://www.beyondblue.org.au/personal-best/pillar/supporting-yourself/i-came-because-i-didn't-want-to-die-jake-s-story-of-anxiety-depression-and-therapy
From a place of hopelessness, Jake has come to accept that he's worth recovering for.
It was Jake’s first session with a psychologist.
And this question would be the first of many he'd confront from this armchair over the coming two and a half years.
While it was hard to answer, Jake realised that for the first time in his 22 years, he wanted to find the answers.
“I knew that I was essentially broken,” he says.
“My attitude was, crack me open and pour me out onto the table. Let’s figure this thing out.”
I'm in this by myself.
I have someone that I can talk to and get a perspective from.

Source: BEYOND BLUE STORY https://www.beyondblue.org.au/personal-best/pillar/supporting-yourself/i-came-because-i-didn't-want-to-die-jake-s-story-of-anxiety-depression-and-therapy
From a place of hopelessness, Jake has come to accept that he's worth recovering for.
It was Jake’s first session with a psychologist.
And this question would be the first of many he'd confront from this armchair over the coming two and a half years.
While it was hard to answer, Jake realised that for the first time in his 22 years, he wanted to find the answers.
“I knew that I was essentially broken,” he says.
“My attitude was, crack me open and pour me out onto the table. Let’s figure this thing out.”
I'm in this by myself.
I have someone that I can talk to and get a perspective from.
